byline.contributor: Matthew Rosenberg and Steven Lee Myers reported from Washington, and Nicholas Kulish from New York. Reporting was contributed by Hwaida Saad from Beirut, Lebanon, Falih Hassan and Omar al-Jawoshy from Baghdad, employees of The New York Times from Erbil and Anbar Provinces, Iraq, Mohammad Ghannam and Nabih Bulos from Paris, and Tim Arango from Essex Junction, Vt.
byline.original: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG, NICHOLAS KULISH and STEVEN LEE MYERS

abstract: People who have lived, or are now living, inside Iraqi and Syrian territory controlled by Islamic State say group has set up predatory bureaucracy designed to extract money, in form of taxes, fines and tolls, from those who live in or pass through its territory; some estimates put total revenue garnered from denizens of group's territory at close to $1 billion per year, and consensus has emerged that this revenue is larger source of funding than money brought in from activities like smuggling oil or looted antiquities.
lead_paragraph: The earnings from the militants’ violent collection practices total tens of millions of dollars a month, approaching $1 billion a year, according to some estimates.

headline.main: Predatory Islamic State Wrings Money From Those It Rules
headline.print_headline: How ISIS Wrings Cash From Those It Now Controls

snippet: The earnings from the militants’ violent collection practices total tens of millions of dollars a month, approaching $1 billion a year, according to some estimates.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations
